faqs.question: What is Sales and Marketing?
faqs.answer: The exchange of goods and services for money is referred to as sales . It is the process of moving goods from the manufacturer to the distributor, the distributor to the wholesaler, the wholesaler to the retailer, and the retailer to the customer. Relationship-building between the buyer and the vendor is the main focus of modern sales, while marketing teams make efforts to create brand awareness of the company's goods, and services. Marketing also involves the process of researching and analyzing customer needs. Read More: Difference between Sales and Marketing

faqs.question: What does MBA Sales and Marketing do?
faqs.answer: Sales and Marketing are two business disciplines that have an impact on lead creation and income. All acts that lead to the sale of products and services are referred to as sales. Marketing is the process of generating interest in the goods and services for sale. Sales and marketing play a special and crucial function in building a connection between potential customers' demands and the goods and services the company has to offer. Students who have completed their graduation with minimum 50 per cent score can apply to this programme. Students can join various industries and make an average salary ranging INR 4 to 8 lakh per year after the course at the entry-level.

faqs.question: What are the benefits of Pursuing MBA in Sales or MBA in Marketing?
faqs.answer: Sales and Marketing are very important departments in any company. Both sales and marketing teams have different processes, but their aim is the same i.e. generating revenue for the company and increasing its popularity and profitability. MBA in Marketing focuses on sales and marketing management as well as planning, organizing, and controlling management elements, which aids in job placement following the degree. Only individuals with a three-year bachelor's degree in any discipline or a BBA program from a recognised institute or university are eligible for an MBA in Marketing .

faqs.question: Why should I pursue MBA in Marketing?
faqs.answer: MBA Marketing will enhance the skills of the students willing to enter this field. MBA in Marketing will upgrade their abilities relating to decision-making and managerial skills expand their growth prospects in the future and also help them in climbing the success ladder. MBA in Marketing degree will also open many doors for them and they will be able to enter various industries including advertising, retailing, banking , marketing, and research.

faqs.question: Who should study MBA in Marketing?
faqs.answer: Students who have completed their BBA in Sales and Marketing or graduated from any stream can opt for an MBA programme in Sales and Marketing . Working professionals also have the option to pursue an Executive programme in Sales and Marketing so that they can complete their studies without quitting the job. The MBA in Marketing professionals can also pursue certification courses to enhance their knowledge and improve their pay scales

faqs.question: What is the difference between marketing and sales?
faqs.answer: For any company selling a product, the concepts of marketing and sales are very important, as they can mean the difference between success and failure. While they are often used interchangeably or grouped they are two different concepts and it is important to understand those differences. Sales refers to the short-term need to close a sale, get an agreement signed, or ultimately do what needs to be done to sell whatever it is you are selling. Sales techniques and strategies are based on what it takes to 'close the deal', which is crucial to any business. If you get customers in the door but cannot get them to buy a product, there is a problem with your sales strategy. Sales strategies are focused on the individual buyer and what needs to be done for them to pull out their wallet, or click on the buy button when it comes to online selling. Companies typically set sales volume targets for a period (weeks, months, and quarters) and have strategies in place where the individuals responsible for actually selling can make those targets. Marketing is a longer-term concept than sales and relates to forward-looking strategies to understand customer needs, influence customer perceptions, and identify how a company can capitalize on that. The result of the marketing process, and what it directly supports, is making sales easier. Marketing techniques and strategies are based on what it takes to identify the right product mix, the prices for those products, and what needs to be communicated to target customers (via advertisement) to ensure successful sales. One of the key aspects of marketing strategies is building a brand identity for what a company is selling and this varies from company to company. McDonald's obviously brands its food and advertising far differently than a luxury steakhouse would do. While sales are the 'push' to buy the product once the customer is there, marketing is the 'pull' that gets the customer to you in the first place. When marketing is done effectively it can also make sales a far easier job for a company, as the customer can already be convinced and ready to buy by the time they enter your store (or website). Sales can still succeed without very effective marketing but it certainly makes the job more difficult.

career.title: Career After MBA in Marketing: Salary 2026, Jobs, Top Recruiters, Placements

content.text: Sale is an evergreen and continuously rising career. The demand for salespeople is available in almost every industry.  Any person with minimum skills and interests can enter this field and grow within an organisation. The salespersons also have the option to join the marketing or customer service departments.

Also, sales jobs are increasing at a fast pace with more focus on delivery and customer satisfaction. A career in sales revolves around customers' wants and needs. It is rightly said that the customer is "King". It is the primary responsibility of a sales executive to ensure that the customer is getting what he is looking for. A person with good interpersonal skills is most suited for this position.

More and more youngsters are getting inclined towards this area of work due to the number of job opportunities available. However, the job of the salespeople is not just restricted to providing products or services to their customers, but building long-term relations through trust.
Why choose sales?

The sales manager is a lucrative career option in sales and marketing with many growth opportunities. The pay scale, however, differs from company to company depending on the qualification, experience, and skills of the students. The pass-outs of top MBA colleges get placement in multi-national companies at a good pay scale.

Notably, the rate of hiring amongst management or equivalent degree graduates across India stood at 17% percent in 2020 compared to 13% in 2019. In India, the salary of a sales manager ranges between ? 2- ? 4 Lakhs and goes up to ? 14 – ? 20 Lakhs with an average annual salary of ? 5 – ? 9 Lakhs. This figure improves greatly with experience.
Sales span every business and every industry. From top companies to small businesses everyone needs salespeople.
Career in Sales

There are many kinds of positions available in sales. Sales development representative (SDR), Inside sales representative, Outside sales representative, Account executive (AE), Account manager, Sales manager, Customer success manager (CSM) Sales engineer, Sales operations manager, Regional sales manager, Director of sales, Vice president (VP) of sales, Chief sales officer and so on. We have highlighted the top positions available in sales down below.

1. Account Executive/Enterprise Sales- These sales executives work in B2B sales and are responsible for selling products/services and managing a corporation's most important customers. An MBA degree can help you climb the corporate ladder, but it requires experience to attain a sales position at the enterprise level. An enterprise sales executive’s job responsibilities are much greater than sales representatives at lower levels because they are in charge of the largest purchasing clients. Due to this they also earn more.

2. A Sales Consultant- It is a professional who is responsible for creating strategies for promoting the products or services they’re selling. They act as middlemen between the companies and the customers, keeping in mind the latter's requirements. Their jobs are target-based.

3. Real Estate Agent- Realtors work in the real estate industry, they represent buyers, sellers, or both. They handle everything from marketing to closing the paperwork. There is no need for a specific degree, no minimum qualifications are required to become a real estate agent in India. There is no mandatory course or field of study for this profession and anyone can enter in this business. This field requires one to have great communication and negotiation skills, build a reputation, contacts, and comprehensive knowledge regarding the industry.

4. Medical Device/ Pharmaceutical Sales Representative- Representatives here sell medical equipment to medical professionals. They also visit healthcare workers and convince them to buy products from their company. Pharmaceutical representatives on the other hand tend to visit medical institutions in order to drive higher prescriptions for the drugs they are representing

5. Insurance Sales Agent- An insurance sales agent provides clients with information on different kinds of insurance and helps them select a policy best suited for their needs. It is an entry-level position that does not require any specific educational qualification of someone.  As an insurance sales agent, you can work in different sectors selling life insurance, automobile insurance, medical, or household insurance.

6. Software Sales Representative- These professionals are responsible for selling a company’s software to different businesses and entrepreneurs. One must be tech-savvy enough in order to understand and explain the technology they are trying to sell.

7. Consumer Packaged Goods/Wholesale Director- A CPG sales director’s job is not limited to selling packaged goods; they are also involved in a company’s business operations. They are brand managers in many ways for companies dealing with toys, groceries, beverages, and other packaged goods. They maintain a network of buyers and develop profitable relationships and continuously attract more contacts.

8. Account Manager- The job responsibilities here are a combination of sales and customer support where they have a specific clientele to who they provide their services to regarding the products and services. They must build profitable relationships with the customers to drive sales for an organisation. They are also answerable to customers when it comes to queries and demands. Through this, they also identify potential opportunities that can help their organisation prosper.

9. Campaign Manager - A campaign manager is a professional responsible for overseeing the planning, execution, and analysis of marketing campaigns. A Campaign Manager typically refers to a person responsible for planning, executing, and overseeing various aspects of marketing campaigns. This role exists in the realm of marketing and advertising, especially in digital marketing.
Scope of Career in Sales

Account Director or supervisor, Account Manager or Senior Account Manager, Account Executive, Junior Account Executive, Marketing Manager, Assistant, Marketing Manager, Copy Editor, Brand And Product Manager, Copywriter, Event and Trade Show manager, Event and Tradeshow coordinator, Manufacturer’s Representative, Direct Consumer Sales, Corporate Sales, Sales Management are all positions that can be classified under the umbrella of sales 1showcasing the wide variety of jobs one can apply for.

Most commerce-based educational backgrounds are suitable for entry-level jobs in advertising, marketing, promotions, and sales managerial jobs, but many employers prefer those with experience in related occupations plus a broad liberal arts background.
Marketing sector

Sales and marketing go hand in hand, they are crucial pillars of every corporation. They act as a catalyst for generating revenue and more importantly, profit. While marketing is about building a sense of awareness about a particular brand and organization, sales turn that viewership and interest into profits by converting potential customers into actual ones.
Finance sector

The sales department focuses mainly on expanding the organization's customers, and the finance department focuses on achieving a set level of profitability for the company. An organization relies on a healthy relationship between its sales and finance departments.
Healthcare sector

Meaningful audience engagements are crucial for the health and medical organizations, It fosters institutional growth and prosperity. Success in these fronts yields benefits of viability and vitality for given health services organizations, but it also encourages audiences to attend to their healthcare wants and needs. The mutual benefits gained by communicating well are given utmost importance and at remain at the forefront of thought for healthcare providers, prompting them to pursue marketing communications excellence in the same way as they do healthcare delivery excellence.
IT Sector

As the technology sector continues to grow and multiply, so do career opportunities. Software sales careers are amongst the most robust in technology, offering proper job security and potentially huge earning potential for people at the highest ranks.
